text: [Music]
what can we do in in in business and
policy to sustain uh the remarkable
promise that America represents how do
we cut in to the federal policy agenda
for too long business and society have
been fighting against each other These
adversarial relationships have
compounded an era of win-lose politics
and resulted in gridlock here in
Washington We've got to get this turned
around and we've got to do it fast I was
once at a briefing at the House of
Representatives for staff The FLCIO and
the US Chamber of Commerce don't do that
many common briefings But this one was
one we were both eager to do How it was
really vital for US competitiveness that
we uh move boldly uh on infrastructure a
junior staffer sort of she sheepishly
raised his hand and said "The AFL CIO
and the Chamber of Commerce agree on
this Why hasn't it happened?" Answering
that question is something that business
leaders ought to focus on Why is it that
when you get that kind of consensus that
the political system doesn't respond we
had an incredibly diverse uh population
respond to the survey And the great news
is our respondents identified enormous
strengths that are viewed as being even
stronger over time in the US The problem
is these strengths are increasingly
neutralized by other historical
strengths that are weakening over time
So we can see some troubling trends that
are that are holding back the US economy
You might be interested in knowing how
do the respondents from just within the
DC area uh compared to the overall set
of respondents across the world For the
political system you're actually even
less optimistic than the typical
respondent So what we've done uh to get
the discussion started is to actually
identify uh these seven areas that we
believe based on our research really
really matter for US competitiveness
These are areas where there's really a
wide consensus They will have impact uh
in our lifetimes Washington's going to
have to grapple with a lot of these
questions in a pretty profound and quick
way after the election A lot of people
in the world want to live in America and
we have to make sure that we can capture
that talent and keep it here A
high-skilled immigration bill is not
going to move without some opportunities
expanded for US nationals and it's
frankly continuing the drag on the
American economy of our failure to close
the higher education competitiveness gap
uh with our global competitors Your
concern about the tax code is literally
off the charts We need a more
progressive tax uh uh policy where uh
our resources are going to the most uh
productive enterprises Companies are
investing all around the world and
they're not facing that 35% tax rate
corporate tax They're keeping money
abroad and they're never paying those
residual taxes We need continued reform
of US export policy We want to be
encouraged to create businesses in the
US and export products overseas A 100
years ago Boeing was one man Bill Boeing
with an idea We have to get ideas out of
the lab and into re into use creating
enterprises There are thousands of
Boeings being created every day We are
not making the investments that we need
to make in 21st century infrastructure
of all kinds energy transportation uh
telecommunications Business is sitting
on the sidelines with tons of capital in
part because of the uncertainty that
Washington is creating Nobody knows what
our deficit picture is going to look
like No one knows what our tax code is
going to look like You provided a very
powerful analytical frameworks These are
exactly the sorts of things on which we
ought to be legislating Uh it is very
difficult to move from areas of quiet
private consensus to the actual passage
of a bill in today's Congress Coming
from the private sector one of the
surprising things to me is how much you
can effectively do as the federal
government and then how much you can do
if you are partnered with the business
community Every one of you in this room
that's running a business uh let's make
a commitment to do this And if we do
that we can at at least some level
change the world And I think if we can
do that in business we are going to be
looked at differently as businesses
[Music]
